titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0139, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Armenian. Section numbers in the margins against the text. Pentecostal lection numbers and concordances recorded in the lower margins. Words and passages omitted in the main text have been added in the left or lower margins. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 6.
The manuscript is commonly known as Gospels of the Fluting Shepherd because of its marginal miniature of a shepherd making music (fol. 150v).
Marginal vignettes of portraits and arabesques.

canonTables.p: Citations of concordant gospel sections are framed by architectural columns. These support headpieces of multi-colored floral, foliate, and geometric designs upon which large birds stand.

headpieces.p: Headpieces of multi-colored floral, foliate, and geometric motifs at each gospel's opening (fols. 7r, 93r, 145r, and 231r), and with the copy of Eusebius's letter to Carpianus (front pastedown).

initials.p: The major initial of each gospel's opening line is formed by an Evangelist symbol: Matthew (angel, 110 mm), Mark (lion, 38 mm), Luke (ox, 92 mm), and John (eagle, 120 mm). Minor initials are formed by figures of birds or flowers.

watermarks.p: Watermarked blank leaves (16th century) inserted before the gospels of Mark, Luke, and John.

physDesc.extent: 291 leaves, of which 1 leaf, once part of the first quire, now functions as the front pastedown.

foliation.p: 1 (unfoliated paper pastedown) + 290. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil 1-290.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 180 x 125 mm (fol. 9r). Each column is 180 x 55 mm with a space of 15 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 21 lines. Ruling with hard point.

handDesc.p: Written chiefly in bolorgir script in black ink. Each gospel's first line is inscribed in capitals of multi-colored birds, beads, and leaves. Second and third lines are written in erkatâ€™agir script.

condition.p: Margins trimmed presumably during rebinding, thus marring marginal miniatures and decoration. Several leaves are lost. Inner margins of many leaves are reinforced with strips of tape or paper inscribed with unidentified text. Occasional creases. Dirt and grease stains.

binding.p: Bound in blind tooled red morocco over pasteboard. Nail holes are present and the outline of a cross once attached. Remnants of index tabs.

origin.p: The manuscript is thought to have been written in either the 15th or 16th century. A place of origin is unknown.

provenance.p: Medieval to 20th century provenance unknown. University of Chicago bookplate (fol. 1r).

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

overview.p: Four gospels in Armenian. Section numbers in the margins against the text. Pentecostal lection numbers and concordances recorded in the lower margins. Words and passages omitted in the main text have been added in the left or lower margins. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Arm. 6.
The manuscript is commonly known as Gospels of the Fluting Shepherd because of its marginal miniature of a shepherd making music (fol. 150v).

msItem.summary: Eusebius of Caesarea (ca. 260-ca. 340), letter to Carpianus, on the gospel canons.
Canon tables have been bound out of order. For the correct sequence: II (fol. 3r); III (fol. 2r); IV (fol. 4v); V (fol. 5r); VI (fol. 6v); IX and X (fol. 1v). Tables lost, I, VII, and VIII.
Pericope: The Woman taken in Adultery (incomplete).

overview.p: Marginal vignettes of portraits and arabesques.

minItem.minDesc: Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea, Palestine, Portrait: Eusebius, dressed in liturgical vestments, holds an open scroll.
Evangelist, Matthew, Portrait: Matthew, seated in left margin, his hand rests on adjacent bird initial.
Evangelist, Mark, Portrait: Mark, seated in right margin, his hand extended to indicate adjacent text.
Shepherd, Making music: Shepherd plays a pipe in left margin, a wineskin hanging over his shoulder.
Evangelist, Luke, Portrait (damaged): Luke, seated in right margin, his hand extended to indicate adjacent text and bird initial.
